s.text: The life and the work are bound together by this single character trait: not so much the instinct to create as the compulsion to erase.
The life and the work are bound together by this single character trait: not so much the instinct to create as the compulsion to erase.
It would be more true to say that Gopnik's need to see Picasso as a rascal deforms his view of Picasso's art.

("Picasso was born in 1881," notes James Fenton in the New York Review of Books . "To accuse a man of cowardice for not having joined up in 1939 when he was in his late fifties strikes me as a complete novelty, and it would have been a novelty to those Allied soldiers who, on the liberation of Paris, flocked to Picasso's studio as a place of pilgrimage."

People with the predatory instincts that led Picasso to become an artist in late 19 th century Spain become takeover specialists or basketball players or filmmakers in our culture.

This makes all the more puzzling a strain in the critical response not only to Richardson but also to Picasso: a tendency to dismiss his art because of his life.

A friend describing Picasso racing back and forth between the Greek and Roman rooms in the Louvre says he "paces around and around like a hound in search of game."

It was only a matter of time before family values entered art criticism.
He is able to see that scholars have been covering up the crimes of the artist to protect him from justice.
